channel.title: The New Yorker — Reporting
channel.description: Latest reporting from The New Yorker

item.title: Gideon Lewis-Kraus on Rebecca West’s “The Crown Versus William Joyce”
item.description: The writer took on the trial of Lord Haw-Haw, a British Fascist who became a mouthpiece for the Nazis, and who prefigured the reactionary toadyism of our own era.

item.title: Jennifer Lawrence Goes Dark
item.description: She has been cast in maternal roles since her teens. Now, playing a mother for the first time since becoming one, she has chosen the part of a woman pushed past the edge of sanity.

item.title: Inside the Data Centers That Train A.I. and Drain the Electrical Grid
item.description: A data center, which can use as much electricity as Philadelphia, is the new American factory, creating the future and propping up the economy. How long can this last?

item.title: Some People Can’t See Mental Images. The Consequences Are Profound
item.description: Research has linked the ability to visualize to a bewildering variety of human traits—how we experience trauma, hold grudges, and, above all, remember our lives.

item.title: Trump and the Presidency That Wouldn’t Shut Up
item.description: His posts and rants are omnipresent, ugly, and unhinged. Don’t look to history to make it make sense.

item.title: Ed Caesar on Nick Paumgarten’s “Up and Then Down”
item.description: A story about a man trapped in an elevator for forty-one hours has just the right amount of anxiety.

item.title: The Runaway Monkeys Upending the Animal-Rights Movement
item.description: A troop of macaques escaped one of the largest primate-breeding facilities in America. Now a strange coalition of uncompromising activists andMAGAloyalists is demanding that all lab animals be set free.

item.title: The Case That A.I. Is Thinking
item.description: ChatGPT does not have an inner life. Yet it seems to know what it’s talking about.

item.title: Who My Child Was and Would Be
item.description: When Nat transitioned, I learned that when someone you love changes, you change, too.

item.title: Joachim Trier Has Put Oslo on the Cinematic Map
item.description: His new film, “Sentimental Value,” is another intimate character study set in the Norwegian capital. His approach to directing is as empathic as his films.
